newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: SAfrica chemical sector set for new bargaining era.
newsitem.headline: SAfrica chemical sector set for new bargaining era.

text.p: South African chemical industry employers and unions said on Tuesday they signed an agreement in principle on centralised bargaining in the industry.
The agreement was signed as the new Labour Relations Act came into effect on November 11, ushering in a new era in the development of South Africa's labour law.
Representatives from both groups said in a joint statement the agreement laid the foundation for the drafting of a constitution for the establishment of a National Bargaining Council in the industry.
The agreement provided for seven sectors in the industry which would serve the interests of diverse economic groupings.

"The levels at which specific issues are to be bargained have been agreed as has the power relationship between sectors and the National Bargaining Council," employer caucus convenor Fanie Ernst and labour caucus convenor Muzi Buthelezi said.

"It is the hope of all parties that this agreement will establish a new generation of bargaining council that will serve its members in the best possible way in an increasingly global economy," they added.
Interim wage negotiations with one of the major unions in the sector, the Chemical Workers Industrial Union, resulted in an increase of 10 percent this year.
An estimated 80,000 workers are employed in the chemical sector.
